> Anyway, I think what you are saying actually is the kind of answer I 
> w=
ould have  hoped to hear to my question, or at least it is the kind 
> of a=
nswer I might have expected if their answers had been more 
> detailed.  

=
Excellent!!  I have successfully answered a question better than
Dawkins!! =
 WOO HOO!!  8^)

I think that your description of biologist-centric respons=
es
(mechanism) vs. computationalist-centric responses (implementation) is
 =
very well placed.  One is effectively deconstructionist while the
other is =
constructionist and many, many debates have gone round in
circles between t=
hese two groups.

I also agree 100% that those of us working in EC are like=
ly going to
make discoveries that a biological researcher may miss.  The mo=
st
interesting part is that the EC researcher is observing an emergent
proc=
ess rather than deconstructing a pre-existing system.  The
obviously diffic=
ult aspect is to establish a hypothesis for what led
to the emergence.  Fin=
ding parallel processes in biology serves as
validation.  The obvious first=
 step is to provide a medium from which
unexpected results can emerge.  NEA=
T goes a long way toward this by
allowing significant structural innovation=
s.  

A bit of an aside, the ability to establish modularity may be a
signi=
ficant next step.  Most EC applications are limited in this
capacity.  I'm =
not sure if NEAT is fully compatible with modularity or
not - thoughts?

Ex=
cellent discussion!  I look forward to hearing other opinions...

-Kirk

--=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Kirk=
, I've been having similar problems where a message I post never 
> shows u=
p.  I think yahoo is having issues.  I suggest that anyone who 
> posts thr=
ough online forms make a copy of your message before 
> sending it.
> 
> An=
yway, I think what you are saying actually is the kind of answer I 
> would=
 have  hoped to hear to my question, or at least it is the kind 
> of answe=
r I might have expected if their answers had been more 
> detailed.  
> 
> =
Yet I personally would not really take the answer in that direction 
> if I=
 had been asked my own question (and of course I am biased!).  
> The probl=
em is that I do not think that mechanisistic descriptions 
> (e.g. how a ge=
ne is transcribed) are necessarily the right level 
> abstraction for expla=
ining how complexity is represented and 
> searched.  Don't get me wrong- u=
nderstanding the actual mechanisms 
> does provide clues to the underlying =
explanation, but they do not in 
> themselves capture it.  
> 
> It's easy =
to get into a debate on what an "explanation" actually 
> means.  AI resear=
chers usually hold a really high standard for 
> explanation, which is that=
 a good explanation tells you how to 
> implement something yourself.  So f=
or example, if you have an 
> explanation of intelligence, it should tell m=
e how to build it.  If I 
> can't do that, then it's not reaching the tresh=
old.  AI is sometimes 
> criticized for having such an absurdly high standa=
rd for theoretical 
> validation.  Nevertheless, I think that I personally =
tend to 
> sympathize with the implementation-centric mentality.  I want to=
 know 
> how to do it myself.
> 
> And I think that kind of thinking leads =
to higher levels of 
> abstraction.  Sure, there may be in effect more than=
 30,000 genes, 
> for a variety of physical reasons.  Yet there are even on=
ly 
> 3,000,000,000 base pairs in the entire human genome.  That is still 
=
> magnitudes below 100 trillion.  Not that such an argument invalidates 
> =
the idea that information can be combined in different ways- of 
> course t=
hat is exactly what's going on- but the question is, how 
> exactly?  
> 
>=
 And my thoughts like many in EC gravitate towards ideas in indirect 
> enc=
oding, which has grown up mainly in EC.  Of course, for myself and 
> my st=
udents, this line of thought has culminated in the 
> HyperNEAT/CPPN style =
of explanation, which is that in effect 
> regularities are discovered that=
 can be expressed as functions of 
> space and thereby encode spatial patte=
rns.  As those regularities 
> evolve, they are elaborated upon, which at a=
 high level of 
> abstraction means that they are composed with yet more 
>=
 functions.  The nice thing about such a process is that you 
> can easily =
discover simple regularities early (thereby addressing the 
> issue of sear=
ch, the second part of my question), and they form a 
> scaffold for future=
 elaboration.  Furthermore, it creates patterns as 
> a function of Cartesi=
an space, which is what you need to do if you 
> are going to create someth=
ing situated in a physical/geometric 
> universe.  The explanatory appeal o=
f this idea, which is 
> substianally more abstract than the nuances of RNA=
->protein encoding, 
> is that you can actually implement it, so it's an AI=
-style 
> explanation.
> 
> Of course, if it is a proper abstraction, the e=
xplanation must 
> ultimately reduce down to the mechanisms of biology, whi=
ch I believe 
> it does.  In particular in Meinhardt's "Theoretical aspects=
 of 
> pattern formation and neuronal development" 
> (http://www.eb.tuebin=
gen.mpg.de/departments/former-departments/h-
> meinhardt) you can see how g=
enetic regulatory networks in biology in 
> effect encode chemical gradient=
s into spatial patterns that form the 
> basis of other more complex spatia=
l patterns situated in the 
> coordinate frames of the original gradients. =
 The term I like to use 
> is "a plan upon a plan upon a plan."
> 
> In any=
 case, that is the direction I would go with answering such a 
> question m=
yself, which is influenced by biology but not as physically 
> mechanistic =
as biologists often prefer to be.  
> 
> ken
>

om, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:

> > First off, I apologize if th=
is is a double post.  It appears that my

> > Ken'=
s initial question of 30,000 genes determining a 1 trillion
> > connection =
brain is incomplete.
> > 
> > While there may be around 30,000 genes in our=
 genome, don't forget 
> the
> > central dogma of molecular biology:  DNA -=
> RNA -> Protein.  Once 
> DNA
> > is transcribed to RNA, RNA is processed =
and can result in multiple
> > variants which can then lead to subtle diffe=
rences in the translated
> > proteins.  An example is the Retinoid X Recept=
ors.  On particular
> > subset, i.e. RXR-alpha, has one gene but multiple i=
soforms resulting
> > from RNA variants.  Each of these has subtly differen=
t activities 
> with
> > respect to retinoid binding, DNA specificity, tran=
scriptional 
> control,
> > etc.  This effectively amplifies the number of =
apparent genes we 
> have.
> > 
> > Also, not all genes are expressed in al=
l cells.  Cells have somewhat
> > specific controls over what genes are exp=
ressed, to what level they
> > are expressed, and when they are expressed. =
 This gives each cell 
> type
> > a different proteome that specifies that =
cells behavior and 
> function.  
> > 
> > Just to add to the complexity, p=
roteins will be influenced by the
> > milieu in which the are present.  For=
 example, tamoxifen has been
> > commonly used as an anti-breast cancer age=
nt due to its ability to
> > antagonize the estrogen receptor, which is req=
uired for growth of 
> some
> > breast cancer tumors.  In cervical cells, h=
owever, tamoxifen acts as
> > an AGONIST.  Based upon the cellular context =
in which the receptor 
> is
> > present, tamoxifen exhibited different role=
s.
> > 
> > The fractal analogy used in one of the replies is somewhat 
> a=
pplicable
> > and I would extend this to an analogy with Steering Behaviors=
 (as
> > exemplified by Craig Reynolds).  In both these systems you have a =

> very
> > simple set of rules leading to very complex behaviors.  Given t=
he
> > complexity of protein expression and its role in determining cell
> =
> behavior, the resulting set of highly complex rules provides a 
> medium
=
> > in which emergence of brain and mind can occur.
> > 
> > -Kirk
> >

earch space isn't being searched for, say, a human-like solution

ngs,
